metadata.title: Driver Drowsiness Recognition System Using Raspberry Pi
metadata.description: This paper introduces a Driver Drowsiness Recognition System to enhance road safety by continuously monitoring the alertness of drivers. The system uses the Raspberry Pi 4B as the main controller and combines image processing with fatigue detection algorithms. A switch-based system monitors seatbelt use, while a camera conducts continuous monitoring prior to and during driving. The system has several levels of safety built into it, such as detection of alcohol consumption, seatbelt checks, and real-time observation of drowsiness and yawning through computer vision methods. Facial features are examined to identify fatigue signs, and a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model scans eye and face conditions to detect drowsiness. When fatigue indicators are sensed, warnings are presented by a buzzer and vibration motor, and repeated warnings will ultimately cause an imitation vehicle shut down. The system proposed herein provides a intelligent, responsive, and efficient mechanism for preventing fatigue-induced accidents.
keywords: Driver Drowsiness Recognition, Rasp- berry Pi 4B, Real-time Alerts, Road Safety, Driver Safety Systems
references: 1.	Singh, R., & Sharma, A. (n.d.). Eye-blink based driver drowsiness detection system. International Journal of Computer Applications, 169(9), 1–5.
2.	Patil, S., Rane, M., & Kulkarni, A. (2019). Real-time driver drowsiness detection using facial features. International Research Journal of Engineering and Technology (IRJET), 6(3), 5295–5299.

3.	Raut, P., & Kshirsagar, P. (2017). Smart car system with alcohol detection, seatbelt monitoring, and accident prevention. International Journal of Advanced Research in Computer and Communication Engineering, 6(5), 360–364.
4.	Kale, M. P., Deshmukh, A., & Joshi, S. (2021). Raspberry Pi based driver drowsiness detection system. International Journal of Science and Research (IJSR), 10(6), 992–995.
5.	Naik, P., & Gaikwad, R. (2021). Driver fatigue detection using OpenCV. International Journal of Innovative Research in Computer and Communication Engineering (IJIRCCE), 9(7), 6372–6376.

metadata.title: Hábitos alimentarios e imagen corporal en estudiantes universitarios sin trastornos alimentarios
metadata.description:
Resumen / Abstract

Este estudio transversal tuvo como objetivo determinar la frecuencia de actitudes y conductas autoinformadas asociadas con los trastornos de la conducta alimentaria (TCA) en estudiantes universitarios sin diagnóstico clínico. Se evaluaron variables como la insatisfacción corporal, la preocupación por el peso y los hábitos alimentarios, encontrando una prevalencia significativa de comportamientos de riesgo, especialmente entre las mujeres. Los resultados subrayan la necesidad de intervenciones preventivas en el ámbito universitario para abordar estos factores de riesgo.
references: Garner, D. M., Olmstead, M. P., & Polivy, J. (1983). Development and validation of a multidimensional Eating Disorder Inventory for anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. International Journal of Eating Disorders, 2(2), 15–34.

Toro, J., Salamero, M., & Martínez, E. (1994). Prevalencia de los trastornos de la conducta alimentaria en una población escolar española. Actas Luso-Españolas de Neurología, Psiquiatría y Ciencias Afines, 22(4), 172–178.

data.title: Hábitos alimentarios e imagen corporal en estudiantes universitarios sin trastornos alimentarios

metadata.title: Los trastornos de la conducta alimentaria en estudiantes universitarios españoles
metadata.description:
Resumen / Abstract

Este estudio examina la prevalencia y características de los trastornos de la conducta alimentaria (TCA) en una muestra de estudiantes universitarios españoles, con el objetivo de identificar factores de riesgo asociados al contexto académico y sociocultural. Se aplicaron instrumentos psicométricos validados a una muestra representativa, analizando variables como el género, la autoimagen corporal, la preocupación por el peso y los hábitos alimentarios. Los resultados evidencian una mayor vulnerabilidad en mujeres jóvenes, así como una correlación significativa entre insatisfacción corporal y conductas alimentarias disfuncionales. Estos hallazgos subrayan la necesidad de intervenciones preventivas en el ámbito universitario y la promoción de hábitos saludables desde una perspectiva psicoeducativa.
references: Garner, D. M., Olmstead, M. P., & Polivy, J. (1983). Development and validation of a multidimensional Eating Disorder Inventory for anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. International Journal of Eating Disorders, 2(2), 15–34.
Raich, R. M. (1998). Anorexia y bulimia: Trastornos alimentarios. Madrid: Pirámide.

data.title: Los trastornos de la conducta alimentaria en estudiantes universitarios españoles

metadata.title: VLSI Methodology for Implementation of Iris Recognition Based on Singular Value Decomposition for Feature Extraction
metadata.description: In an Iris recognition System Feature extraction plays a very important role were the only useful dominant information from an eye images are extracted. The SVD algorithm is most focused in this paper were the SVD implemented in both Matlab and FPGA along with the Comparison results. The singular value decomposition is dimensionality reduction algorithm were Jacobi transform is used for parallel and fast computation; paper also focuses on the area and timing analysis. Jacobi algorithm for SVD calculation  is used as it contains a large degree of parallelism. Architecture of SVD core which is implemented consists of 6 sub blocks and all are designed in FPGA were the 77% of overall area is utilized by 40x40 iris template image on target device in 211μsec time.
keywords: Jacobi method,SVD core,Timing and Area analysis
references: 1.	Ignacio Bravo*, Pedro Jimnez, Manuel Mazo, Jos Luis Lzaro, Alfred Gardel "Implementation Of Jacobi Method To Solve The Eigenvalue And Eigenvector Problem",2006.
2.	Brent. R.P and Luk, F.T. "An Efficient Jacobi-like Algorithm for Parallel Eigenvalue Computation", IEEE transactions on computers, vol. 42,no. 9, September 1993.
3.	B.G. Patil, "Human iris pattern recognition using phase components of image", IEEE Conference on Industrial and Information System (ICIIS),DOI:10.1109/ICIINFS.2009.5429900,PP:10-14.
4.	Patil. Ashwini.B, Dr.Mrs.V.Jayashree,, "Segmentation Using Daugman"s Algorithm", International Journal of Latest Transaction in Engineering and Technology, paper_id: IJLTET-2018-2404.
5.	[Online].Available:http://www.cbsr.ia.ac.cn/IrisDatabase/irisdatabase.php.

6.	Lee Aing, Toshiaki Kondo, "Eye State Recognition Using The Hamming Distances Of Eye Image Intensities", IEEE 8th International Conference Of Information and Communication Technology For Embedded System(IC-ICTES), DOI:10.1109/ICTEmSys.2017.7958767, pp:1-5.
7.	B.G.Patil, Nikhil Mane, "Iris feature Extraction and Classification in FPGA", International Journal of Electrical and Computer Engineering (IJECE) VOL.2.April 2012, pp.214-222.

journal.title: Journal of VLSI Design and its Advancement

metadata.title: The Role of Battery Recycling in the Electric Vehicle Lifecycle
metadata.description: The global shift towards electric vehicles (EVs) is an important step in addressing climate change and reducing carbon emissions from the transportation sector. While EVs are often seen as an environmentally friendly alternative to internal combustion engine vehicles, the impact of their battery production, usage, and disposal must also be considered in their full lifecycle. This paper explores the role of battery recycling in the lifecycle of EVs, focusing on its environmental, economic, and technological implications. It also addresses the current state of battery recycling practices, challenges, and innovations in the field. By promoting more sustainable recycling solutions, the EV industry can reduce its overall environmental footprint and create a more sustainable and circular economy.
keywords: Electric Vehicles (EVs),Battery Recycling, Lithium-ion Batteries, EV Lifecycle, Sustainable Transportation, Battery Second Life, Circular Economy, Resource Recovery, End-of-Life Management, Recycling Technologies, Environmental Impact, Battery Materials (Lithium, Cobalt, Nickel),Energy Storage, E-waste Management
references: 1.	Goodenough, J. B., & Park, K. S. (2013). The Li-ion rechargeable battery: A perspective. Journal of the American Chemical Society, 135(4), 1167-1176.
2.	Li, X., & Yang, Y. (2021). Battery recycling in the electric vehicle era: Challenges and opportunities. Journal of Cleaner Production, 293, 125751.
3.	Zhang, L., & Duan, H. (2020). Lithium-ion battery recycling: A review. Journal of Power Sources, 452, 227766.

metadata.title: A воз и ныне-ка там. К истории частицы КА в русском языке [And the things are still the same. On the evolution of the particle KA in Russian]
metadata.description:
In this talk, given at the 2025 Memorial Zaliznjak's Readings, I discuss the evolution of the particle KA in Russian.  This enclitic particle expresses the meaning of soft encouragement in standard Modern Russian and attaches to imperative forms or ininitial proclitics like NU that can are semantically equivalent to imperatives. A close semantic parallel is provided by the Danish imperative particle LIGE that conveys a similar meaning. However, in the Russian dialects and in the Russian language of the XIX century, the particle KA is also used as a proximal deictic marker 'here and now' or 'towards the speaker' and attaches to other clitic hosts, e. g. personal pronouns (MNE-KA), wh-words (GDE-KA), etc. Max Vasmer in his Etymological Dictionary (vol. 1, 1964) takes for granted that the deictic KA (which has Slavic parallels) and imperative KA represent the single element. However, Vladimir Orel (2007) in his Etymological Dictionary accepts Igor S. Vahros's hypothesis (1984) that the imperative KA is a recent Russian innovation rooted in rapid colloquial speech and based on the allegro-variant of some focus particle going back to Proto-Slavic *toliko. He claims furthermore that the initial form is neither -KA, nor -KO, but -TKO ( < TOKO < TOL'KO < TOLIKO) and assumes that the imperative -KA /-KO /-TKO was absent from Old Russian. This theory, attractive as it is, must be rejected ipso facto since the imperative KA is safely documented by the Old Novgorod Birch bark letters № 109 and 854 dating with XII century, while deictic KA is attested in the same epoch by the Birch Bark letter 652. Moreover, the Birch bark letter № 1002 (XII century) already contains the compound deictic particle KO-VO, known from Northern Russian dialects. Andrej A. Zaliznjak (1993, 2004, 2008) correctly classified Old Russian KA as a 2P particle conforming to Wackernagel's law, though he stated that the data is too scanty to predict the place of KA in Old Russian clitic clusters.  Regarding the Birch bark letter № 109, where KA attaches to the clause-initial adverbial NYNĔ, Zaliznjak initially (1989) assumed that NYNĔKA is a single lexical element characteristic of South-West Russia, though in 1993 he converted to the syntactic analysis with Wackernagel's law. Zaliznjak's first hypothesis was later supported by Polekhov & Krysko (2021) and Gippius et. al. (2023) provided that the author of the Birch bark letter № 109, certain Zhiznomir, indeed had clear Old South Russian features in his idiolect. However, the probable South Russian origin of Zhiznomir does not undermine the syntactic analysis of  NYNĔ=KA since the context is unequivocally imperative. 

Comments.

  1.  The Acknowledgments, incl. the gratitudes to the conference participants are on slide 29 of the revised presentation. All disclaimers follow.
  2.  On the reasons of space, I don't discuss the important contribution of Pertsov (1996) claiming a morphological approach to the imperative KA in Modern Russian. This paper is listed in the References. Neither do I discuss Levontina's claim (2019) that the particle KA tends to expand its syntactics in Modern Russian. This paper is listed in the References, too. The checking of these claims requires an analysis of corpus data which is beyond the reach of this paper.
  3. Andrej A. Zaliznjak's views of the Old Russian particle KA and its occurrences in the epigraphic documents have changed substantially in the period from 1989 to 1995 ― a detail which might be of interest for his biographers. In 1989, see [НГБ VIII] in the References, he clined towards a morphological analysis of NYNĔKA in the Birch bark letter № 109 (early XII century) but mentioned the cryptic spelling [T]OUTE KA <wrote X> 'X wrote right here' in the graffito (Медынцева 1978, № 212). If he assumed a syntactic approach in 1989, he should treat  NYNĔ=KA 'right now' on a par with TOUTE=KA 'right here'. In 1993, see [НГБ IX: 285 ] in the References, he already mentions that Birk barch letters 109 and 682 contain the enclitic particle KA but do not mention the (Медынцева 1978, № 212). In the first edition of "Old Novgorod Dialect" (1995), Zaliznjak does not treat -KA in NYNĔKA from the Birch bark letter № 109 as a suffix but do not comment its status as a clitic either. This gap is filled in the 2nd edition of "Old Novgorod Dialect" (2004: 259), where  NYNĔKA from № 109 is explicitly analyzed as NYNĔ=KA, i. e. as a clitic host NYNĔ + enclitic =KA. The same syntactic interpretation is taken in the book Zaliznjak (2008). Finally, in 2018, Savva V. Mikheev (see the 'Related Works' section) showed the reading [T]OUTE KA <wrote X> 'X wrote right here' in the graffito (Медынцева 1978, № 212) is a phantom,. Therefore, this Novgorod graffito must be excluded from the list of Old Russian documents containing the particle =KA.

metadata.title: Synthesis and Characterization of Schiff Base Reagent Derived from o-Phenylenediamine and 2-Hydroxy-1-Naphthaldehyde and prapare there monometallic complexes
metadata.description:
Abstract:

In this study, a Schiff base reagent was synthesized by reacting o-phenylenediamine with 2-hydroxy-1-naphthaldehyde to form a Schiff base ligand. The ligand was characterized using various spectroscopic techniques including UV-Vis, IR, NMR, and mass spectrometry, confirming the successful formation of the desired compound. The ligand's structure was further confirmed through elemental analysis, revealing the expected stoichiometry. Subsequently, monometallic complexes of the Schiff base ligand were prepared by coordinating the ligand with transition metal ions such as Cu(II), Ni(II), and Co(II). The resulting metal complexes were characterized by techniques such as UV-Vis, IR, and X-ray diffraction to assess their structural properties. These complexes showed promising stability and coordination behavior, indicating their potential applications in catalysis and coordination chemistry.

metadata.title: Predicting Flight Prices by using Neural Networks and Regression
metadata.description:
The objective of the Flight Fare Prediction System is to help travellers plan their trips and manage their finances by offering accurate estimates of flight ticket prices. Frequent variations in airfare for the same flight often pose challenges for securing economical options. This predictive model resolves such issues by estimating ticket prices, helping users save money and understand price trends better. The strategy makes use of sophisticated machine learning techniques and historical flight data to ensure dependable fare predictions. Key factors, such as departure times, airlines, travel dates, destinations, and other pertinent information and analysed to discern patterns influencing pricing.

The system incorporates a number of machine learning strategies, such as Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Support Vector Regression. By delivering fare estimates and insights into pricing trends, this system enables users to make informed booking choices. Its integration into flight booking platforms provides a useful resource for travellers to find cost-effective options and plan trips with ease.
keywords: Machine learning, neural networks, and airline fare forecasting, Flight Data Analysis.
references: 1.	Tziridis, K. (2017, October 26). Flight prices prediction using machine learning techniques. 25th Conference on European Signal Processing (EUSIPCO), IEEE.

metadata.title: Voice-Driven Medical Department Recommendation: Integrating Named Entity Recognition with Distinct Clustering and Multi-Class Classification on Unlabeled and Labeled Data For Enhanced Analysis
metadata.description: Through the integration of cutting-edge natural language processing techniques, this multidisciplinary research project seeks to improve the accuracy and reach of voice-driven medical department classification. For nuanced language comprehension, K-means clustering efficiently divides data using Clinical BERT. Integrating the Med7 and BC5CDR models helps Named Entity Recognition (NER) by making it easier to thoroughly identify and categorize things in medical records. In order to enhance contextual analysis and capture sequential relationships, LSTM networks are used for multi-class classification in conjunction with distinct BiLSTM and CRF models. To improve the classification process, a CNN model is also included to extract features from input data. This integrated framework provides useful insights into voice-driven medical record analysis and advances automated healthcare systems by working seamlessly with both labeled and unlabeled data. It has a great deal of potential to revolutionize the field. The following are the model accuracy rates: CNN 97%, CRF 78%, LSTM 76%, and BiLSTM 67%. Unlabeled patient data was grouped using K-means clustering, which shed light on how symptoms impact cluster formation and convergence.
keywords: Medical Department Recommendation, Named Entity Recognition, K-means Clustering, Conditional Random Field, Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers
references: 1.	Miah, M. S. U., Sulaiman, J., Sarwar, T. B., Islam, S. S., Rahman, M., & Haque, M. S. (2023). Medical named entity recognition (MedNER): A deep learning model for recognizing medical entities (drug, disease) from scientific texts. IEEE EUROCON  2023 - 20th International Conference on Smart Technologies, 158–162.
2.	Liu, N., Hu, Q., Xu, H., Xu, X., & Chen, M. (2022). Med-BERT: A pretraining framework for medical records named entity recognition. IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics, 18(8), 5600–5608.

metadata.title: Predicting Medal Counts In Olympics Using Machine Learning Algorithm
metadata.description: The major international sports that occur once in every four years are Olympics ,has more than 200 participant nations. It is used for preventing whether the Atlantic is too winning a win a medal in the Olympic game . the studies on Olympic are expecting to predict the total number of medals of The nation and possible to achieve further or country’s performance All the country should do analyse to evaluate previous performance so they get to know their mistake and help to grow in the further. Machine learning in particular boosting algorithms, it has an influence it improves in prediction models.
keywords: Olympic game, machine learning algorithm, Olympic medals predication.
references: 1.	Ahmed, Y. A., Ahmad, M. N., Ahmad, N., & Zakaria, N. H. (2019). Social media for knowledge-sharing: A systematic literature review. Telematics and Informatics, 37, 72–112.
2.	Fink, A. (2019). Conducting research literature reviews: From the Internet to paper (5th ed.). Sage.
3.	Houlihan, B., Leopkey, B., & MacIntosh, E. (2017). Introduction: Youth, sport and the Youth Olympic Games. International Journal of Sport Management and Marketing, 4/5/6, 237–241.
4.	Bellavia, S., Macconi, M., & Morini, B. (2003). An aMne scaling trust-region approach to bound-constrained nonlinear systems. Applied Numerical Mathematics, 44, 257–280.
5.	120 years of Olympic Dataset, Available: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/heesoo37/ 120-years-of olympic-history-athletes-and- results.

6.	Deepak, N. R., & Balaji, S. (2016). Uplink channel performance and implementation of software for image communication in 4G network. In R. Silhavy, R. Senkerik, Z. Oplatkova, P. Silhavy, & Z. Prokopova (Eds.), Software engineering perspectives and application in intelligent systems (Vol. 465). Springer.

7.	Pal, R. S., & Deepak, N. R. (2024). Evaluation on mitigating cyber attacks and securing sensitive information with the Adaptive Secure Metaverse Guard (ASMG) algorithm using decentralized security. Journal of Computational Analysis and Applications, 33(2), 656–667.
8.	Omprakash, B., Metan, J., Konar, A., Patil, K., & Chiranthan, K. K. (2024). Unravelling malware using co-existence of features. Proceedings of ICAIT 2024, 1–6.

9.	Rezni, S., & Deepak, N. R. (2024). Challenges and innovations in routing for flying ad hoc networks: A survey of current protocols. Journal of Computational Analysis and Applications, 33(2), 64–74.

10.	Deepak, N. R., & Balaji, S. (2015). Performance analysis of MIMO-based transmission techniques for image quality in 4G wireless network. In 2015 IEEE International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Computing Research (ICCIC) (pp. 1–5).
